trial_identification.studytitle: Sleep Disorders in Bronchiolitis Obliterans Syndrome 2&3
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The Prevalence and Treatment of Sleep Disorders in Lung Transplant Recipients With BOS 2 & 3 and the Influence on Quality of Life and Daytime Activity.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other inflammatory or immune system disorders

interventions.interventions:
Treatment: surgery - Assessment of sleep disorders and treatment if required
Experimental: Bronchiolitis Obliterans 2 & 3 - Assessment of sleep disorders and treatment if required
Active Comparator: Bronchiolitis Obliterans 0 - Assessment of sleep disorders and treatment if required
Treatment: surgery: Assessment of sleep disorders and treatment if required Assessment of sleep disorders and treatment if required

primaryOutcome.outcome: To Measure Prevalence of sleep disorders in Bronchiolitis Obliterans 2&3 patients - Using level one laboratory based polysomnograph

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life assessment using Rand SF36 standard survey - Participants will complete Rand SF36 standard survey for Quality of life. This will be completed at baseline visit and at 6 and 12 months post sleep study
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, 6 and 12 months after sleep study

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
- Patients who are post lung, heart lung and heart lung liver transplant with bronchiolitis obliterans 2 & 3
- Comparative group -Patients who are post lung, heart lung and heart lung liver transplant with bronchiolitis obliterans 0
- Identified possible sleep related disorder
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- Subjects who do not provide informed consent
- Subjects unable to understand the study and related procedures
- Patients with a life expectancy of less than 6 months

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study is to determine whether sleep disorders contribute to impaired quality of life and mobility in patients with Bronchiolitis Obliterans syndrome and whether non invasive positive airways pressure ventilation can improve sleep, quality of life and mobility in this patient group.

contact.name: Andreas Fiene, BA Med,Surg. FRACP MD
